BE11:15am

Here's Goldman to summarise.

BE11:15am

IHG reported its 3Q19 trading update this morning (October 18), with system-wide RevPAR slowing further as expected to -0.8% in 3Q19 (-0.5% excluding Hong Kong impact). System growth was softer at 4.7% yoy (vs. 5.7% in 2Q19), but management remains confident of exceeding 5% net system growth for the full year (vs. GSe: 5.5%).
We think investors will likely take negatively today comments on slowing RevPAR and a more cautious outlook, given continuing deterioration in group bookings in the US and also uncertainty in Asia that looks set to continue in 4Q. That said, RevPAR weakness should be partially in the price given the well-flagged impact from macro uncertainty in HK and China. We would also expect investors to focus today on the slower system growth (4.7% in 3Q), however management attributes the slowdown to timing and comps of last year, expecting to be exceed 5% for the full year.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Key points:
RevPAR growth: Group RevPAR decelerated to -0.8% in 3Q19 (vs. -0.2% in
n2Q19), driven by weakness in Hong Kong (30bps impact on group RevPAR) and continuing weakness in the US.
Americas: US RevPAR growth in 3Q was -0.6% (vs. -0.7% in 2Q19),
opartially affected by renovation activity but also an underlying slowdown in group activity (especially in autos and manufacturing). Overall Americas RevPAR was -0.6% yoy, with growth in Latam/Caribbean of +6% and Canada -2%.
EMEAA: RevPAR growth was +0.2% in 3Q19 (vs. +0.7% in 2Q19; GSe
o2H19: +1.6%). The growth was driven by UK (+1%, with London +3%) and Continental Europe (+1%, with France +1% and Germany -7%). Middle East RevPAR was down 1%.
Greater China: RevPAR growth in Greater China was -6.1% yoy in 3Q19,
odriven by the situation in Hong Kong (-36%). In mainland China, IHG’s RevPAR was down 2% in 3Q, outperforming the industry.

BE11:16am

And Morgan Stanley off the call.

2s10s hi
BE11:16am

The CFO was positive on IHG's business model's performance allowing it to broadly meet FY expectations (including a one-off gain), expected to achieve the 80-120bps fee margin target this year, put most of the Q3 RevPAR weakness down to one-off factors (e.g. HK unrest, trade tensions), and sees FY unit growth exceeding 5%. The main negatives were the commentary on some underlying softness in the US (small meetings, autos/manufacturing), a flag on 2020 China profits if HK unrest continues, the inclusion of $10m non-recurring income which helps meet expectations, and a weak unit growth performance (slowed to ~4% excluding Six Senses/Macau alliance). On forecasts, the company signals FY19 EBIT consensus of $865m should come down by ~$5m for HK, but that it should also include the $10m one-off, suggesting a ~$15m underlying downgrade (taking it to MSe $850m, +2% yoy), though we note this still implies a stronger H2 than H1. For 2020, consensus of $915m looks too high to us given it implies 8% underlying EBIT growth (MSe $880m currently). Both Accor and IHG's results suggest we could be seeing the beginning of a synchronised global downturn, but there is a lot of political noise that can be blamed, so neither company is yet taking action on cost, and both expect unit growth to offset RevPAR weakness.

Ulster Pension Fund morning all
tangledodyssey Would the future trade deals with the EU need parliamentary approval or are they entirely within the government's remit? I'm wondering whether refusing Johnson an election would be a means of keeping the purgatory going for a while longer by then making life unbearable in the HoC?
AMALtd morning

BE11:19am

In a break-neck 12-hour period, we have had profit warnings from Accor and IHG and the worst monthly US RevPAR (revenue per available room) print since February 2010. Some softer trading was expected, but the quantum of the weakness is still disappointing, despite the headline guidance commentary from both companies covering up bigger underlying downgrades, of c2% in both instances.

There are problems all round for the major hotel groups. If things continue as they have started this quarter, the large hotel franchises are on track for their weakest quarter since the financial crisis.

BE11:26am

Here's Jefferies to summarise.

Soundbuy Reasonable performance since IPO
BE11:26am

Avast released its 3Q results update, reporting adj. revenue of $218.3m implying organic CC growth of +9.0% vs. FY consensus of +8.1%. 3Q adj. EBITDA of $121.9m (EBITDA margin: 55.3%) is broadly in line with consensus/JEFe margin expectations for the FY at c.55%. The company indicated billings grew broadly in line with adj. revenue in 3Q, implying YTD billings growth ahead of total revenue growth. Owing to Avast's billings model, it enjoys a high degree of visibility over its revenue; a strong 3Q along with continued strong billings positions the company to meet its full-year targets. The company reiterates its full year guidance for adj. revenue to be at the upper end of high single digit growth at CC and broadly flat adj. EBITDA margin (excl. the IFRS 16 impact of approx. 100bps YoY). We expect shares to react positively on the back of the results with room for cons. upgrades, noting YTD adj. revenue growth of 9.1% at CC is ahead of FY19 consensus growth numbers.

BE11:27am

2020 Key Debate: Capital Allocation. We expect Avast to achieve a leverage ratio of approx. 2.0x net debt to LTM Adj. Cash EBITDA by the end of 2019, with a further reduction to 1.5x by the end of 2020. We note that the company has stated a mediumterm leverage floor of 1.5x. As a reminder, the company has currently committed to paying out 40% of levered FCF as a dividend and currently prioritizes excess funds towards deleveraging. Reaching the leverage floor opens up the possibility for the company to either conduct additional shareholder returns post-2020 or to pursue inorganic opportunities to continue scaling the business (e.g. SMB).

FATDAZ seems to me that remainers have been wrong footed by yesterdays event Jeremy Corbyn was saying last night that the deal would drive us into the arms of Donald trump has he not noticed the two year post deal negotiating period and the fact that DT is likely to be impeached and or face re-election in next 12 months?
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Avast Remains One of our Top Picks. Avast's 3Q results continue the company's track record of consistent execution of both growth and profitability since its IPO in early 2018. The stock currently trades at approx. 16x EV/2020E FCF and we forecast 2020 total revenue growth of approx. 8%. This compares to the broader European software sector that has a median EV/2020E FCF of 30x.

BE11:33am

UBS:

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Q; How did the results compare vs expectations?

Avast reported Q3 underlying revenue growth of 9.0%, consistent with the trend of 9.1% seen in Q1 and 9.3% in Q2. Revenues of $220m are in-line with us at $218m and cons. at $219m. It also leaves Avast on track to deliver on its unchanged target for the year to be at the "upper end of high single-digit revenue growth". EBITDA came in at $122m, growing in-line with sales at 8.7%. A year-to-date EBITDA margin of 55.4% leaves Avast on track to deliver on its unchanged guidance for stable margins in the year (before IFRS 16 effects of +100bp). We are at 55.0% and consensus is at 55.1%. Adjusted billings growth was described as being similar to underlying adjusted revenue growth of 9%; a slowdown from H1's 12.5%, albeit as expected given the phasing of product launches. Year-to-date, billings growth is ahead of sales growth.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

Detailed commentary on the drivers of the performance was minimal, but we believe the trends from H1 have continued with Desktop growth on track to deliver "high single-digit to low double-digit" revenue growth in the year (H1: 10.5%). We believe this is mainly driven by cross-selling and upselling. Mobile continues to be weighed down by the Sprint ramp-down but direct-to-consumer sales are stronger, led by new product launches. Consumer Indirect, meanwhile, continues to see traction for the Avast Secure Browser and good Jumpshot growth, which is now starting to leverage the new Ascential relationship. Cash paid by Ascential for its 35% stake (c$60m) in Jumpshot helped net debt fall to 1.9x EBITDA by period end.

2s10s @CrowK: have you seen Paul Mason https://twitter.com/paulmasonnews/status/1185135615937044481
BE11:33am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?

No, guidance is unchanged. Consensus is looking for Q4 sales of $225m; a $5m q/q increase which is consistent with the $4m seen last year. Avast makes reference to the 435m users of its platform, pointing to a stable – and still sizeable – opportunity for commercialisation around protection, privacy and performance.

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

The revenue and billing trends are reassuring and are a further data point in establishing a record of consistency in execution that should aid a re-rating of the shares. We expect a positive reaction.

Brexit – Saturday night fever

11:36 am
BE11:36am

This is BNP Paribas.

BE11:37am

Saturday’s vote on the UK’s withdrawal agreement
with the EU is likely to be extremely close in our
view. As things stand, our bias is for the deal to be
rejected by the UK Parliament.
Moreover, there is lingering uncertainty about the
future UK-EU relationship, both in terms of the
process of agreeing it and its impact on the UK
economy.
Nonetheless, with an agreement between the UK
and EU now struck, the range of possible outcomes
has shifted in a more market-positive direction, in
our view.
In terms of ultimate outcomes, both deal and
revocation have increased in likelihood, whilst no
deal has decreased, we think.

nightingale20201 @Forester..Corbyn needs more than a make-over....Labour BREXIT policy, at best has been described, as ambigous

Kiwi-juice AVAST. Reminds me of F-Secure in Finland. Business model is based on getting paid the first year because HP/Dell ships you in anyway. And banking on people forgetting the remove auto-renewal the next years
11:37 am
BE11:37am

A deal being agreed between the UK and EU sets
Saturday up to be one of the most important events in
the Brexit saga. There are three possible outcomes:
1) Deal is accepted by parliament.
2) Deal is accepted subject to criteria, eg a
confirmatory referendum.
3) Deal is rejected.
In our view, the latter option is the most likely. Of course,
the situation is very fluid and the parliamentary
arithmetic could yet shift more decisively towards any
one of these three outcomes over the next 48 hours. For

example, at the time of writing it looks as if pro-
referendum MPs are more likely to seek a fresh public

vote at a later stage of the Brexit legislative process,
rather than it being tacked on to Saturday’s vote.

BE11:37am

Parliamentary arithmetic: There are 639 voting MPs.
Assuming no abstentions, the threshold for success is
320. The government currently has 287 MPs (excluding
the Speaker and Deputy Speaker). Even if it is able to
win the support of all 21 MPs who were recently
expelled from the Conservative party, it will still be 12
MPs short of a majority. After all, the DUP have explicitly
rejected the proposals.

BE11:38am

DUP might abstain, of course. Or might not. I've lost track quite frankly.

Tom Dalgleish Nortons does data backup included now
nightingale20201 @BE (Re: UBS note) desktop growth - I thought we had been in laptops @ home/office for years
2s10s These Brexit brokers notes aren't really any better than the national press.
11:38 am
BE11:38am

While the government may be able to rely on the support
of some Labour MPs, the latter may be dis-incentivised to
do so unless the deal looks very likely to go through. In
addition, we think it is optimistic to assume the
government can retain support of all its MPs as well as
the ex-Conservatives. A number of the Eurosceptic ERG
can be expected to vote against these proposals too.
All told, we think a vote on the (unamended) deal is
probably close to 50/50, with our bias being towards it
being rejected. However, again, a lot could change over
the next 48 hours, given that many MPs appear
undecided.

CrowK @2s10s Courage that is beyond their leader it would seem
FATDAZ @Wideness the only spanner in the works there is that labour voters and constituencies were broadly pro brexit see herehttps://twitter.com/berniespofforth/status/1182594365476265984?s=09
BE11:39am

Give us the damn probabilities, BNP.

BE11:39am

Balance of risks skewed more positively: The potential
outcomes are mostly all positive for markets, in our view.
A deal passing would be clearly positive. A deal passing
subject to a referendum likely means either an orderly
Brexit or the UK remaining in the EU, both of which are
positive for markets – with the government united behind
a deal and a majority of MPs opposed to no deal, we don't
think ‘no deal’ would be on the ballot.
Rejection of the deal probably increases the chances of
an election, and it is now much less likely that the
Conservatives would stand on a no-deal platform. As a
result, we think there is less chance of no deal at a later
stage as well.
Probabilities: In light of developments, we revise our
ultimate Brexit probabilities as follows: Deal 55%
(previously 40%). Remain 35% (30%). No deal 10%
(30%).

luzh Sammy Wilson this morning explicitly said they would vote against, not abstain
11:39 am
BE11:39am

And the market implications, pls.

BE11:40am

FX: We expect GBPUSD to rise and possibly exceed
1.33 if a deal is agreed on Saturday. Alternatively,
sterling may pare its recent gains if a deal is rejected,
although the market may be quick to fade any GBP
pullback, with bullish sentiment remaining entrenched.
Rates: We still lean towards trade ideas that will
benefit from the passage of a deal, but with caution:
the potential near-term disappointment could cause
recent optimism to unwind. Spot 10y yield appears
just above our estimate of its fair value for the first
time this year.
Equities: We expect at least a 5% rise in domestic
UK stocks on the deal passing, with or without an
accompanying referendum, and up to 10% downside
for the FTSE 250 if it fails.
Credit: The credit market is pricing in a 23% chance
of no deal, which looks too high to us. We think UK
and High-Yield credit look attractive.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning folks

11:42 am
BE11:43am

The EU heads of state and government yesterday agreed on a Brexit deal. But have we turned the corner? First of all, the deal must be approved by the British Parliament tomorrow, which is by no means certain. Even if the agreement clears this hurdle and businesses are spared a no-deal Brexit, they would still have to deal with the global trade war. Compared to this, Brexit has always been a sideshow.

den @Tang - totally agree - its like the percentage of rain at midday in the weather forecast !
VV75 anything on how much they expect housebuilders to rise on a deal? They've already had quite the run since last week

Can a sideshow also be an ordeal? I guess it can.

2s10s enough Brexit broker notes, that aint no better than what we can find in the newspapers.
FATDAZ @Plato whats changed within the EU for the better since then ?
luzh @nightingale the question is why now and not the last time? I think the answer might be fear of losing seats, including to the Brexit Party
BE11:44am

The agreement between the EU and Britain is a huge step forward. But the treaty must be ratified by the British Parliament, which will meet tomorrow on a Saturday for the first time since 1982. Whether it will ratify the deal is very difficult to predict. The Northern Irish Unionists (DUP) have indicated that they will reject the plan. It is also clear that the Liberal Democrats and the Scottish Nationalists (SNP) will reject it (see table 1). In addition, the Labour Party's leadership is opposed to the agreement.
On the other hand, the deal negotiated yesterday offers the possibility of the clean divorce that most people want. It is therefore quite possible that Boris Johnson will gain the support of the radical Brexit supporters within his own party, but also many of the 21 Conservative MPs who were suspended from the party last month. In this instance, it would only take a handful of Labour dissenters to ensure that the deal could be ratified - albeit by a very narrow margin. But the outcome of the vote is, of course, very uncertain.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

FATDAZ Given that Junker ruled out an extension yesterday if the deal is rejected tomorrow surely no deal is the default position no ?
2s10s @Fatdaz: it is not Juncker's call, it is Tusk's (the EUCO)
BE11:45am

What does this mean for the Pound?
As far as sterling is concerned, a successful deal means that a no-deal risk will start to be priced out of the exchange rate. This has already happened to a large extent in recent days with a significant appreciation of GBP (more than 5% against the USD, around 4% against the EUR). If the remaining uncertainty is removed tomorrow by Parliament's approval, more GBP strength can be expected at the market opening on Monday. In this scenario, is it realistic to assume EUR-GBP will fall back to the levels of late-2015, i.e. in the range 0.70 to 0.75? Such GBP optimism would probably be inappropriate. In contrast to four years ago, it is far from certain - in view of global growth weakness - whether the Bank of England (BoE) will not have to ease monetary policy anyway, regardless of the Brexit risk. Although a good part of the no deal risk in the currency market has already been priced out, almost nobody on the OIS market expects an interest rate hike which the BoE has hinted at in the past in the event of an amicable Brexit. Indeed, many continue to expect an interest rate cut

nightingale20201 @BE....some more £bn grant to DUP may do the trick
FATDAZ @2s10s I see
BE11:45am

11:45 am
BE11:46am

The BoE's monetary policy will be dependent on how much previous investment weakness
was due to Brexit fears (and is therefore quickly recouped) and how much is due to the global
slowdown in growth and a change in the UK's relationship with the EU (i.e. remains permanent).
This is difficult to say right now. But it would be implausible to assume that the United Kingdom
will be able to decouple from the global slowdown in growth.
If Parliament rejects the deal, we can expect significant renewed GBP weakness. Not only
would the GBP appreciation in recent days appear unjustified, but if the EU signals that it will
not accept a further extension, a clear no-deal risk on Monday morning could trigger a very
significant weakening of GBP.

tangledodyssey I love that comment right at the end there, "But the outcome of the vote is, of course, very uncertain.", ie you've just wasted your time reading our rubbish.

What is most concerning is that c.80% of this downgrade is driven by elements that should be largely under Renault’s control. The inability to fully pass through regulatory costs with pricing, a lack of discipline on R&D costs and ramp up issues on new product/cost savings plans all point to elements that are either being mismanaged or are more structural. To compound this
further, at a time when Renault-Nissan have never seemed further apart politically – their operating
performance is perhaps more intertwined than ever.

BE11:51am

Dig deeper and the root cause of Renault’s problems appears to be insufficient brand power and a
lack of real tangible cost savings. Achieving a fully functioning Alliance could solve one side of this
equation – but there are question marks over whether the current structure will ever allow that in its
most powerful form. For us, core Renault now has to focus on product. We estimate its weaker product portfolio (particularly in SUVs) explains c.75% of the EU margin delta vs PSA. However fixing this will not be easy and will take time.

Our detailed financial health screen addresses the many concerns thathave weighed on valuation this year. NMC's extensive use of acquisitions has proven its worth, in our view, while organic growth has remained strong. Elevated working capital has now normalised and long-term cash conversion has been good. Accounting policy concerns appear immaterial. Related party transactions are material, buthave a solid rationale. Despite the rally post-H1 results, the share is down 19% YoY and trades on 18.1x2020e EPS - a discount of 10% to global peers.

BE12:03pm

here are a lot of moving pieces, but ultimately, we make no change to our target price, and our combined EPS changes are minimal. Within the overall valuation, we value M&G at £6.0bn using a sum-of-the parts approach. We sense check this by comparing to peer dividend yields. The £465mn base M&G dividend implies a yield of 7.75%, which compares to 6.6% at Phoenix, 7.0% at Legal & General, 7.9% at SLA and 7.9% at Aviva.

BE12:03pm

To separate the models, we align the M&G earnings projections to the new company disclosure and allocate corporate expense, interest expense and debt between the two entities based on management guidance. We also update our model for the new dividend policies – namely, a stable to growing policy with a base amount of £465mn at M&G and a progressive policy with a base rate of £750mn at Prudential Plc. We assume a 8% p.a. dividend growth at Prudential Plc and 2% p.a. at M&G. We roll forward the asset values for market movements and FX movements since the half year and update sales estimates based on the trading update published in the demerger circular. There are a lot of moving pieces between the two entities, but our combined EPS changes are minimal at -0.8%, -1.2% and +1.2% for 2019e, 2020e and 2021e, respectively. We make no change to our target price.

GBKrona @BE- brill, thanks for PRU
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

We value M&G at £6.0bn. We use a sum-of-the parts valuation, whereby we apply a 13x PE multiple (based on peer multiples) to the savings and asset management business. We value the heritage with-profits business using a 20-year discounted cash flow model (with a terminal value) based on the after-tax shareholder transfers, which runs off in line with company guidance. We value the shareholders’ annuity business using a 20-year discounted cash flow model (with a terminal value) based on capital generation, which runs off in line with company guidance. We then deduct a) the after-tax corporate center and interest expense at a 9x multiple and b) its £3.2bn financial debt.
